questions.stem: According to DSM-5, which feature distinguishes Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) from Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD)?

options.text: OCD is ego-syntonic while OCPD is ego-dystonic
OCD involves intrusive, unwanted obsessions and/or compulsions that cause distress
OCPD has an earlier age of onset than OCD
OCD involves perfectionism and preoccupation with orderliness

questions.explanation: OCD is characterized by intrusive, unwanted obsessions (thoughts, urges, images) and/or compulsions (repetitive behaviors) that are ego-dystonic (distressing, unwanted) and time-consuming. OCPD is a personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of perfectionism, orderliness, and control that is ego-syntonic (consistent with the person's self-image). In OCD, the person recognizes the obsessions/compulsions as excessive or unreasonable; in OCPD, the rigidity is seen as desirable.

questions.stem: Research on the neurobiology of OCD has most consistently implicated dysfunction in which brain circuit?
questions.explanation: OCD research has consistently implicated the cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) circuit, involving the orbitofrontal cortex, striatum (particularly caudate), and thalamus. Hyperactivity in this circuit is thought to underlie the intrusive thoughts and repetitive behaviors of OCD. This is distinct from the amygdala-centered fear circuitry implicated in other anxiety disorders. Effective treatments (SSRIs, exposure with response prevention) normalize activity in this circuit.

questions.stem: Which of the following are classified as Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders in DSM-5? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.explanation: DSM-5's Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders chapter includes: OCD, Body Dysmorphic Disorder (preoccupation with perceived appearance flaws), Hoarding Disorder, Trichotillomania (hair-pulling), and Excoriation Disorder (skin-picking). These share features of repetitive behaviors and obsessive preoccupation. Illness Anxiety Disorder (D) is classified under Somatic Symptom and Related Disorders, not OCD-related disorders.

questions.stem: Evidence-based treatments for OCD include which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: SSRIs at higher doses than used for depression
Deep brain stimulation for treatment-resistant cases

questions.explanation: Evidence-based OCD treatments: ERP (exposure to obsession triggers without performing compulsions) is first-line psychotherapy (A); SSRIs are effective but often require higher doses than for depression and take longer to work (B); cognitive therapy targeting inflated responsibility and overestimation of threat (D); deep brain stimulation is FDA-approved for treatment-resistant cases (E). Benzodiazepines are NOT effective or recommended for OCD (C is incorrect)—they may even interfere with extinction learning in ERP.

questions.stem: Match each OCD-related symptom dimension to its typical content:

columns.text: Fears of dirt, germs, disease with washing compulsions
Need for things to be 'just right' with arranging/counting
Fears of accidentally causing harm with checking compulsions
Intrusive sexual, religious, or aggressive thoughts

questions.explanation: OCD symptom dimensions: Contamination—fears of dirt/germs/illness, excessive washing/cleaning compulsions. Symmetry/ordering—need for things to be 'just right,' arranging, counting, repeating rituals. Harm—fears of causing accidental harm (leaving stove on, running over pedestrian), checking compulsions. Taboo thoughts—intrusive sexual, religious, or violent thoughts that are ego-dystonic; may involve mental rituals. These dimensions have somewhat different neurobiological correlates and treatment responses.

questions.stem: For each anxiety disorder, select ALL cognitive features typically present:
questions.explanation: Cognitive features: GAD—intolerance of uncertainty (difficulty tolerating not knowing), catastrophic worry chains. SAD—fear of negative evaluation (being judged, humiliated, embarrassed). OCD—intolerance of uncertainty, inflated responsibility (believing one's thoughts can cause harm), thought-action fusion (believing thinking about something makes it more likely or is morally equivalent to doing it). These cognitive features are targets in cognitive therapy for each disorder.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about OCD:

[BLANK1] are recurrent, intrusive thoughts, urges, or images that cause marked anxiety. [BLANK2] are repetitive behaviors or mental acts performed to reduce anxiety or prevent a dreaded outcome. For a diagnosis of OCD, symptoms must be [BLANK3] (taking more than 1 hour per day) or cause significant distress. The gold-standard psychological treatment is [BLANK4], which involves exposure to obsession triggers while preventing the ritual response. OCD is now classified in its own chapter in DSM-5 called Obsessive-Compulsive and [BLANK5] Disorders.
questions.explanation: Obsessions are intrusive, unwanted thoughts/urges/images causing anxiety. Compulsions are repetitive behaviors/mental acts performed to reduce anxiety. OCD must be time-consuming (>1 hour/day) or cause significant distress/impairment. Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the gold-standard psychotherapy. DSM-5 moved OCD from anxiety disorders to its own chapter: Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old man spends 4+ hours daily checking that doors are locked, appliances are off, and windows are closed. He knows the checking is excessive but fears that if he doesn't check, something terrible will happen due to his negligence. The checking significantly interferes with work and relationships.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the MOST likely diagnosis?

options.text: Intrusive fears of causing harm through negligence

questions.explanation: This is OCD with harm obsessions (fear of negligently causing harm) and checking compulsions. Key features: obsessions (intrusive fears), compulsions (checking rituals), time-consuming (4+ hours), ego-dystonic (recognizes as excessive), functional impairment. Treatment involves ERP (exposure without checking) and potentially higher-dose SSRIs. OCPD would be ego-syntonic (proud of orderliness). Benzodiazepines are NOT first-line for OCD.

questions.stem: A psychiatry resident is studying OCD treatment guidelines. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the first-line psychological treatment for OCD. (B) SSRIs are effective for OCD but may require higher doses than used for depression. (C) Benzodiazepines are the most effective medication for OCD. (D) ERP involves exposure to feared stimuli while preventing compulsive rituals. (E) Cognitive therapy targeting inflated responsibility can be helpful for OCD. (F) Response to medication is typically seen within 1-2 weeks. (G) Clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant) has efficacy for OCD.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) ERP is first-line psychotherapy; (B) SSRIs effective but often need higher doses; (D) ERP combines exposure with ritual prevention; (E) Cognitive therapy targets beliefs like inflated responsibility; (G) Clomipramine has demonstrated efficacy. Incorrect: (C) Benzodiazepines are NOT effective for OCD; (F) OCD medication response typically takes 8-12 weeks, not 1-2 weeks.

questions.stem: Arrange the typical OCD treatment algorithm steps from FIRST to LAST:

options.text: Consider deep brain stimulation for refractory cases
Augmentation with antipsychotic or switch to clomipramine
Increase SSRI dose if partial response

questions.explanation: OCD treatment algorithm: (1) First-line: ERP (most effective psychotherapy) and/or SSRI; (2) Dose optimization—increase SSRI to maximum tolerated dose if partial response; (3) Augmentation (add antipsychotic like risperidone) or switch to clomipramine if inadequate response; (4) Neurosurgical interventions (deep brain stimulation) only for severe, treatment-refractory cases. ERP remains important throughout, as medication alone is often insufficient.

questions.stem: Categorize each symptom/feature according to whether it is characteristic of OCD, GAD, or Both:

items.text: Intrusive, unwanted thoughts experienced as foreign to the self
Excessive worry about realistic life concerns
Ritualistic behaviors performed to reduce anxiety

questions.explanation: OCD-specific: Intrusive ego-dystonic thoughts, rituals/compulsions, thought-action fusion (believing thoughts can cause harm or are morally equivalent to actions), inflated responsibility. GAD-specific: Worry about realistic concerns (vs. bizarre/unrealistic in OCD), somatic symptoms (muscle tension, restlessness), chronic free-floating anxiety. Both share difficulty controlling mental activity, though the content differs (obsessions vs. worry).
